questions.question: A speedskater increases their velocity from an initial value of $2.0\text{ m/s}$ to a final value of $14.5\text{ m/s}$ over a distance of $32\text{ m}$. Assuming constant acceleration, calculate the magnitude of this acceleration.

A remote-controlled car is traveling at a constant velocity of $8.0\text{ m/s}$ when its battery dies, causing it to coast to a stop with constant deceleration in $12.5\text{ s}$. Calculate the total distance covered by the car while it is coasting.

A coin is dropped from rest into a deep well, and the sound of the splash is heard $4.2\text{ s}$ later. Neglecting the time taken for the sound to travel back up the well, calculate the depth of the well. Assume free fall under gravity with $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.

A juggler throws a club vertically upward from hand level. The club returns to its starting point $1.6\text{ s}$ later. Calculate the magnitude of the initial upward velocity imparted to the club. Neglect air resistance and assume $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.
questions.explanation: Time to top = $0.8\text{ s}$. Using $v = u + at$: $0 = u - 9.8(0.8) \rightarrow u = 7.84 \approx 7.8\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A rescue plane flies horizontally at a constant speed of $145\text{ km/h}$ at an altitude of $220\text{ m}$ above level ground. The plane releases a care package. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the horizontal distance the package travels from its release point to the point of impact.
questions.explanation: $v_x = 145/3.6 = 40.28\text{ m/s}$. Fall time: $220 = 4.9t^2 \rightarrow t = 6.70\text{ s}$. Horizontal distance: $d = 40.28 \times 6.70 \approx 270\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A projectile is launched from ground level with an initial speed of $36\text{ m/s}$ at an angle of $48^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the total time of flight until the projectile returns to ground level.
Determine the maximum height reached by a projectile launched from ground level with an initial speed of $25\text{ m/s}$ at an angle of $20^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. Neglect air resistance.

A swimmer can swim at a constant speed of $1.1\text{ m/s}$ in still water. They head directly across a river that is $40\text{ m}$ wide, aiming perpendicular to the banks. If the river current flows at $0.6\text{ m/s}$ parallel to the banks, how far downstream from their starting point will the swimmer land?
questions.explanation: Time to cross: $t = 40/1.1 = 36.36\text{ s}$. Downstream distance: $d = 0.6 \times 36.36 \approx 21.8\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A police car moves North at a constant velocity of $120\text{ km/h}$ while chasing a speeder who is also moving North at a constant velocity of $145\text{ km/h}$. Calculate the velocity of the speeder as measured by an observer in the police car (i.e., the relative velocity of the speeder with respect to the police car).
questions.explanation: Relative velocity: $v_{S/P} = v_S - v_P = 145 - 120 = 25\text{ km/h North}$.

questions.question: A box with a mass of $22\text{ kg}$ is pulled across a horizontal surface by a horizontal rope with a tension of $85\text{ N}$. If the box accelerates at $2.5\text{ m/s}^2$, calculate the coefficient of kinetic friction between the box and the surface.
questions.explanation: $F_{net} = ma = 55\text{ N}$. $f_k = T - F_{net} = 30\text{ N}$. $\mu_k = f_k/(mg) = 30/(22 \times 9.8) \approx 0.14$.

questions.question: A book with a mass of $0.50\text{ kg}$ is pushed across a horizontal desk, giving it an initial speed of $3.2\text{ m/s}$. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the book and the desk is $\mu_k = 0.45$, calculate the time it takes for the book to slide to a stop.
Calculate the magnitude of the impulse required to bring a car with a mass of $1450\text{ kg}$ traveling at a speed of $26\text{ m/s}$ to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: Impulse $J = \Delta p = m\Delta v = 1450(0 - 26) = -37700\text{ N·s}$. Magnitude: $3.77 \times 10^4\text{ N·s}$.

questions.question: A block with a mass of $5.5\text{ kg}$ is placed at rest on a frictionless incline that makes an angle of $24^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. Calculate the magnitude of the component of the block's weight that acts parallel to the surface of the incline.

A block slides down a frictionless incline that makes an angle of $40^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. Starting from rest, calculate the time it takes for the block to travel a distance of $5.0\text{ m}$ along the incline.

In an Atwood machine, two masses, $M_1 = 12\text{ kg}$ and $M_2 = 15\text{ kg}$, are connected by a light string passing over a frictionless, massless pulley. Calculate the acceleration of the system when it is released from rest.

A $4.0\text{ kg}$ block on a horizontal table with coefficient of kinetic friction $\mu_k = 0.15$ is connected by a light string over a frictionless pulley to a $2.0\text{ kg}$ hanging mass. Calculate the tension in the string when the system is released.

A small ornament with a mass of $0.15\text{ kg}$ is suspended from the ceiling by two light strings. One string is horizontal. The other string makes an angle of $35^{\circ}$ with the vertical. Calculate the tension in the angled string.

A person with a mass of $55\text{ kg}$ stands on a scale inside an elevator. If the elevator cable snaps and the elevator falls freely under gravity, what is the apparent weight of the person as read by the scale?
questions.explanation: In free fall, $a = g$, so normal force $N = m(g-a) = m(0) = 0\text{ N}$. Apparent weight is zero.

questions.question: A car tire has a radius of $0.32\text{ m}$ and rotates at $850\text{ rpm}$ (revolutions per minute). Assuming no slipping, calculate the linear speed of the car in $\text{km/h}$.
An object moving in uniform circular motion has a centripetal acceleration of $12\text{ m/s}^2$. If the radius of the circular path is $4.5\text{ m}$, calculate the frequency of rotation.

A mass of $0.25\text{ kg}$ is attached to a string and whirled in a vertical circle of radius $1.0\text{ m}$. If the speed of the mass at the bottom of the circle is $8.0\text{ m/s}$, calculate the tension in the string at that instant.
questions.explanation: $T - mg = mv^2/r \rightarrow T = m(g + v^2/r) = 0.25(9.8 + 64) = 0.25(73.8) \approx 18.5\text{ N}$.

questions.question: Calculate the maximum constant speed at which a car of mass $1200\text{ kg}$ can travel over the crest of a circular hump with a radius of curvature of $22\text{ m}$ without leaving the ground.

A rubber stopper of mass $45\text{ g}$ is swung in a horizontal circle of radius $0.80\text{ m}$. If the period of rotation is $0.50\text{ s}$, calculate the magnitude of the centripetal force acting on the stopper.

A car of mass $1500\text{ kg}$ rounds a flat, unbanked curve with a radius of $60\text{ m}$. If the maximum static friction force available is $9000\text{ N}$, what is the maximum constant speed the car can maintain while going around the curve?

Calculate the distance between the centers of two objects, each of mass $1000\text{ kg}$, if the magnitude of the gravitational force of attraction between them is $1.0 \times 10^{-6}\text{ N}$. Use $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}\text{ N·m}^2/\text{kg}^2$.

A moon orbits a planet in a circular orbit at a distance $D$ from the planet's center. If the moon were moved to a new circular orbit at a distance $4D$ from the planet's center, by what factor would its orbital speed change?
questions.explanation: Orbital speed $v \propto 1/\sqrt{r}$. If $r \rightarrow 4r$, then $v \rightarrow v/\sqrt{4} = v/2$. Factor: $1/2$.

questions.question: A block of mass $15\text{ kg}$ is pulled at a constant speed a distance of $8.0\text{ m}$ up a rough incline that makes an angle of $20^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. If the constant kinetic friction force acting on the block is $25\text{ N}$, calculate the work done by the friction force on the block.

A baseball of mass $0.145\text{ kg}$ is moving horizontally at a speed of $40\text{ m/s}$ when it is caught by a fielder. The fielder's glove moves backward $25\text{ cm}$ while bringing the ball to a stop. Calculate the average force exerted by the ball on the glove during the stop.
Calculate the net work required to double the speed of a car of mass $1200\text{ kg}$ that is initially traveling at $10\text{ m/s}$. Assume all work done goes into changing the kinetic energy.

A ball of mass $0.50\text{ kg}$ is fired vertically upward from a spring gun. The spring has a spring constant $k = 550\text{ N/m}$ and is compressed by $0.12\text{ m}$ before firing. Neglecting air resistance and the mass of the spring, calculate the maximum height reached by the ball above its launch point.

A $3.0\text{ kg}$ block slides from rest down a frictionless ramp from a height of $2.5\text{ m}$. At the bottom of the ramp, it continues along a rough horizontal surface where friction brings it to a stop. If its speed at the very bottom of the ramp is measured to be $5.0\text{ m/s}$, calculate the amount of thermal energy generated due to friction on the horizontal surface.
An electric motor with an efficiency of $80\%$ draws $1500\text{ W}$ of electrical power. At what constant speed can this motor lift a load of mass $50\text{ kg}$ vertically upward?
Calculate the horsepower required to lift a $220\text{ kg}$ load vertically upward a distance of $15\text{ m}$ in $10\text{ s}$. Use the conversion $1\text{ hp} = 746\text{ W}$.

A block of mass $2.0\text{ kg}$ moves horizontally at $3.5\text{ m/s}$ and collides with a light horizontal spring with spring constant $k = 1200\text{ N/m}$. Assuming no friction, calculate the maximum compression of the spring.

If $15\text{ J}$ of work is required to stretch a particular spring by $10\text{ cm}$ from its natural length, how much work (in J) is required to stretch it an additional $10\text{ cm}$ (i.e., from $10\text{ cm}$ to $20\text{ cm}$)?
questions.explanation: $15 = \frac{1}{2}k(0.10)^2 \rightarrow k = 3000\text{ N/m}$. Work to $20\text{ cm}$: $\frac{1}{2}(3000)(0.20)^2 = 60\text{ J}$. Additional: $60 - 15 = 45\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A car of mass $1500\text{ kg}$ moving at $15\text{ m/s}$ collides head-on and locks bumpers with a stationary truck of mass $2500\text{ kg}$. Assuming the collision is perfectly inelastic, calculate the final velocity of the combined wreck immediately after the collision.

A ball of mass $1.0\text{ kg}$ moving at $5.0\text{ m/s}$ undergoes an elastic head-on collision with a stationary ball of mass $4.0\text{ kg}$. Calculate the velocity of the $4.0\text{ kg}$ ball immediately after the collision.

A projectile of mass $0.25\text{ kg}$ initially at rest explodes into two pieces. One piece, of mass $0.10\text{ kg}$, moves away at $24\text{ m/s}$ due East. Calculate the kinetic energy of the other piece, which has a mass of $0.15\text{ kg}$, immediately after the explosion.
A $9.0\text{ V}$ battery is connected in series with a $150\Omega$ resistor and a $330\Omega$ resistor. Calculate the voltage drop across the $150\Omega$ resistor.
Two resistors connected in series have a total equivalent resistance of $500\Omega$. If the ratio of their individual resistances is $1:4$, find the resistance of the smaller resistor.
Calculate the equivalent resistance of three resistors, with resistances of $100\Omega$, $200\Omega$, and $400\Omega$, connected in parallel.
Four identical resistors are connected in parallel. The equivalent resistance of this combination is $22\Omega$. Calculate the resistance of each individual resistor.

A $50\Omega$ resistor is connected in parallel with another $50\Omega$ resistor. This parallel combination is then connected in series with a $25\Omega$ resistor. Calculate the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.

A $12\text{ V}$ battery is connected to a circuit consisting of a $10\Omega$ resistor in series with a parallel combination of two $20\Omega$ resistors. Calculate the total power dissipated in the circuit.
A wave travels a distance of $15\text{ m}$ in $3.0\text{ s}$. If the distance between two consecutive troughs (the wavelength) is $0.40\text{ m}$, calculate the frequency of the wave.
questions.explanation: Speed: $v = 15/3.0 = 5.0\text{ m/s}$. Wavelength: $\lambda = 0.40\text{ m}$. $f = v/\lambda = 5.0/0.40 = 12.5\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: A string of length $0.80\text{ m}$ and total mass $5.0\text{ g}$ is under a tension of $100\text{ N}$. Calculate the fundamental frequency of vibration for this string.

A person standing on a stationary platform hears the whistle of a train. The frequency heard as the train approaches is $550\text{ Hz}$, and the frequency heard as it recedes is $450\text{ Hz}$. Assuming the speed of sound is $v_s = 340\text{ m/s}$, calculate the speed of the train.

Two speakers are separated by a distance of $3.0\text{ m}$ and emit a $680\text{ Hz}$ tone in phase. The speed of sound is $340\text{ m/s}$. At what distance from the center point along the line joining the two speakers is the first point of constructive interference (i.e., the first antinode) located?
questions.explanation: $\lambda = 340/680 = 0.50\text{ m}$. Path difference for constructive: $\Delta = \lambda = 0.50\text{ m}$. $2x = 0.50 \rightarrow x = 0.25\text{ m}$ from center.

questions.question: Calculate the length of a closed-end organ pipe (closed at one end, open at the other) that has a third harmonic frequency of $440\text{ Hz}$. Take the speed of sound as $v_s = 343\text{ m/s}$.

Two waves of the same frequency traveling in the same medium have amplitudes of $5.0\text{ cm}$ and $12.0\text{ cm}$. Calculate the amplitude of the resultant wave when these two waves interfere destructively, being exactly $180^{\circ}$ out of phase.
